Traffic Needs



wherever feasible should form the backbone of Baltimore’s rapid
transit system. The method visualized by Mr. Barnes would
involve the collection of a load on special busways connecting to
the expressways. Some intermediate stops might be made by
using access ramps for a brief return to surface streets. Bus stops
on a high speed expressway are not generally feasible since they
require long acceleration and deceleration lanes. After making
provision for necessary access ramps there are usually few
stretches of urban expressways long enough for these lanes and
even fewer will be located at the right places.

The facts and judgments noted above would appear to produce the
following conclusions:

1. Insofar as we may be hoping to improve our mass transit system
through reliance on express buses, an expressway system is as
desirable or essential to the public transportation system as it is
to private vehicular transportation.

2. If we are thinking in terms of a rail system it can only be in
relationship to serving the central business district.

Let us now explore the second of these conclusions in greater detail.
The purpose of a rail system oriented to serve the central business district
would be, of course, to induce car riders to transfer to rapid transit and
thus reduce the number of cars coming into the central business district.
Since traffic congestion is most acute during rush hours, the problem can
be further narrowed to a consideration of the potential reduction in the
number of cars bringing workers to employment in the central business
district.

Some indication of the range of this potential reduction can be ob-
tained through three separate approaches:

1. A survey conducted by the Planning Council in 1958 indicates

18

that 539 of central business district employees travel to work by
public transportation. How high might this percentage be, given
sufficient improvement of our public transportation system? The
Planning Council, in its Plan for the Central Business District of
Baltimore, has expressed its judgment, based on a survey of other
cities, that at very most this percentage could only be increased
to 689%. The difference of 15% applied against total central
business district employment of 96,000 represents 14,500 persons.
Assuming 115 persons per car the conversion of 14,500 persons
from car to rapid transit would reduce the total number of cars

coming into the central business district during rush hours by

about 10,000.

. The Planning Council survey mentioned above also provides a

different approach to the question. This survey indicated that of
the 96,000 persons employed in the central business district, about
one-quarter, or approximately 24,000, drive cars to work. Of this
number about one-half indicate that they need their cars during
the day for business reasons, or use them for various auxiliary
purposes during the trip to or from work. It is unlikely that this
group could be converted to public transportation regardless of
improvements made. This leaves approximately 12,000 drivers
who theoretically might be converted. If all were converted the
reduction in cars coming into the central business district for
employment purposes would be 12,000.
